member.name: M:GameDevProfi.Utils.Animation.timeScale01(System.Single)
member.summary:
Maps Time.time to a scale of [0..1] when a interval of duration seconds is intended.
This is a reminder/shortcut helper, i.e. for using AnimationCurves: - Define an AnimationCurve with keyframes with from 0 to 1 (horizontal axis). - If you want to get the animation curve value with having one animation cycle be mapped to 2 seconds, use: animationCurve.Evaluate(Utils.timeScale(2f));
member.param: Desired animation duration in seconds.

member.name: M:GameDevProfi.Utils.Animation.timeScale01(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary:
Maps the given time to a scale of [0..1] when a interval of duration seconds is intended.
This is a reminder/shortcut helper, i.e. for using AnimationCurves: - Define an AnimationCurve with keyframes with from 0 to 1 (horizontal axis). - If you want to get the animation curve value with having one animation cycle be mapped to 2 seconds, use: animationCurve.Evaluate(Utils.timeScale(Time.time,2f));
member.param: Time stamp, usually something like Time.time.
Desired animation duration in seconds.

member.summary: Returns the y value from the given curve if the curve should be mapped to a total length of duration seconds. Uses timeScale01(Time.time,duration).

member.name: T:GameDevProfi.Utils.WatchForError
member.summary: Utility to track Unity's errors which cannot be caught by exception catching.

remarks.para:
Example Use Case:
When loading a scene which is not included in the build, Unity will just add an error message to output saying Scene '...' couldn't be loaded because it has not been added to the build settings or the AssetBundle has not been loaded.

A way to react on scene loading failure is to attach an log message output recorder to the application and see if an error occurs while the scene loading attemp is running. This is what this class does.

Usage:
Create and start an instance of WatchForError right before the critical line of code. Use WatchForError.startNew() for this.
Call stop() right after the critical line.
Look at the number of errors and react accordingly.
